name: Acamprosate (Campral)
summary: A medication used to help maintain abstinence in individuals with alcohol use disorder.
description: Acamprosate is a synthetic amino acid derivative that modulates glutamatergic neurotransmission. It is approved for the maintenance of abstinence in patients with alcohol dependence who have achieved sobriety. It is most effective when combined with counseling and psychosocial support.

off_label_uses: Craving reduction in other substance use disorders (limited evidence)
contraindications: Known hypersensitivity to acamprosate or excipients

items: Maintenance of abstinence in alcohol use disorder after detoxification

sections.text: Believed to restore the balance between excitatory (glutamate) and inhibitory (GABA) neurotransmission in the brain disrupted by chronic alcohol exposure.

adult.adjustment: For moderate renal impairment (CrCl 30–50 mL/min): 333 mg three times daily

sections.geriatric: Same as adult; adjust for renal function

sections.text: Therapeutic effect typically begins within 5–8 days of initiation; benefits maintained with ongoing therapy.

other: Monitor mood; may increase risk of depression or suicidal ideation
Ineffective for patients who have not stopped drinking before starting therapy

items: Renal function at baseline and periodically

sections.pregnancy: Use only if potential benefits justify potential risks.
sections.lactation: Unknown excretion into breast milk; use with caution.
sections.geriatrics: Dose adjustment based on renal function.

sections.text: No physiological withdrawal expected; can be discontinued without tapering.

items: Most effective when initiated after detoxification and combined with psychosocial support.
Does not prevent withdrawal symptoms; not indicated for acute detox.
Primarily renally excreted; safe in hepatic impairment.
